Award.AbstractNarration:
With National Science Foundation support, Dr. Michael E. Smith and a team of urban experts at Arizona State University will compare the ways city dwellers gained access to urban services in a sample of thirty ancient and historic cities. Planners and city officials today wrestle with difficult decisions about where to locate schools, clinics, parks, and other facilities. Scholars have found that the locations of some urban services allow particular groups better access than others. This project will identify the ways cities have organized their services throughout history. Non-governmental institutions (churches, guilds, neighborhood associations) have played a significant role in providing urban services in the past. Were these services more equally distributed than those provided by city authorities, or did governments do a better job of equitably providing services to residents? By answering these and other questions about services in ancient and historic cities, this project will give scholars and planners a broader base of knowledge to apply to modern cities around the world.
The research team includes experts from four disciplines-archaeology, geography, political science, and sociology. The co-Principal Investigators are Christopher Boone, Sharon Harlan, and Abigail York, with Senior Scientists George Cowgill and Barbara Stark. They will use concepts and methods from these and other fields to produce a broad picture of urban services in the past. The team will select cities from each of fourteen early urban traditions, ranging from ancient Egypt to Medieval Europe. For each city, the team will digitize historical or archaeological maps that portray housing and service facilities. The maps will then be analyzed spatially in a common framework using the methods of Geographical Information Science to show how the locations of service facilities relate to neighborhoods and the residences of elite and commoner families. The target services include shops/commercial services, religious services, and public assembly places. The team will also study historical or archaeological records for each city to reconstruct its social, economic and political patterns. This contextual information will be coded and analyzed in a common framework, and then the team will compare it to the results of the spatial analysis to determine what kinds of cities, political, and economic systems produce more equal service access for urban populations.
This project has three primary intellectual merits: (1) this will be the most rigorous comparative study of premodern cities yet undertaken; (2) the joint work of a team of scholars from four different scholarly disciplines will produce a particularly broad and comprehensive analysis of urban services; and (3) the application of methods and concepts derived from the analysis of modern urban services to a sample of past cities will produce results that are directly comparable to our knowledge of services in contemporary cities. This is a particularly important topic for the rapidly growing cities in the developing nations.
The broader impacts of this study include training and mentoring for two graduate students and a group of undergraduate interns including Hispanic students. In addition, the scientific knowledge we gather and systematically code about premodern cities will inform research and policy on the role of services contemporary urbanization in two ways: (1) it will provide a large comparative sample of cities for scholars and planners to draw on; and (2) it will provide a long-term historical perspective on cities, services, and urban change.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Dr. Michael E. Smith and a team of urban experts at Arizona State University compared the ways past city dwellers gained access to urban services in a sample of twenty-three ancient and historic cities located around the world. Planners and city officials today wrestle with difficult decisions about where to locate schools, clinics, parks, and other facilities. Scholars have found that the specific locations and institutional providers of some urban services allow particular groups better access than others. This  is the first systematic research project to address this issue for cities before the modern era. We first identified the spatial locations of city services in the sample of urban places, and subsequently investigated the types of government and other non-government institutions, like religious, civic, and commercial groups, that provided urban residents with important services. Non-governmental institutions played a significant role in providing urban services in many ancient cities, and this project probed whether these services were more equitably distributed than those provided by city authorities. This interdisciplinary project transcends narrower approaches to urban historical studies and provides the most rigorous comparative study of premodern cities to date. The research team included experts from four disciplines—Archaeology (Dr. Michael Smith, Dr. Barbara Stark and Dr. George Cowgill), Geography (Dr. Christopher Boone), Political science (Dr. Abigail York), and Sociology (Dr. Sharon Harlan)—and the project was the first to be co-funded by these four separate programs at NSF. The project further advanced interdisciplinary study by including data and academic perspectives from urban history, architectural history, urban planning, and anthropology.

The first major contribution of this project was the collection and analysis of urban services data from twenty-three cities represented by thirteen early urban traditions located on five continents, ranging in age from the ancient Maya to 19th century Africa. Our innovative methods can serve as models for other researchers. For each city, the team collected spatial data from disparate sources, creating digital historical and archaeological maps that portray urban and neighborhood boundaries, housing, and service facilities. The maps were spatially analyzed in a common framework using Geographical Information Science software to show the locations of service facilities relative to neighborhoods and the residences of elite and commoner families. We studied three types of urban service facility: shops/commercial services, religious services, and public assembly places. Adopting measures of equity in service access that are common in modern urban planning, the team used both distance measurements and statistical methods to analyze spatial equity in ancient urban settings. The project team also created an integrated interdisciplinary conceptual framework for understanding access to urban services in cities across history.

The project’s second major contribution involved detailed study of historical or archaeological records for each city to reconstruct the social, economic and political characteristics that might influence observed patterns in service access. This effort included the organization of over ninety types of data for each city that illuminate the city’s governance, religious practices, civic groups, commercial status, ethnic diversity, class mobility, and territorial importance. This contextual information was gathered by undergraduates, and then coded and analyzed in a common framework by senior project members to allow comparison across urban traditions. Our coding method—a novel approach to comparative urban study developed by the project team—was detailed in one of several publications by group members.  All raw and coded data regarding contextual urban patterns are being made publicly available at Arizona State University’s digitcal archaeological repository, tDAR.

Finally, the project team compared spatial patterns of service access to the contextual socio-political data to determine what kinds of urban systems produce more equal service access for urban populations; this research effort will continue into the future as we are exploring all possible correlations. We found that religious facilities tend to be more evenly distributed in cities than were other facilities, whereas assembly spaces were more restricted in their distribution, providing poorer access. Preliminary results suggest that the size and shape of cities, regardless of political orientation, may exert significant effects on equity of service access. The nature of government—whether more autocratic or more collective—also affected access to services. The broader impact of this project—aside from published articles and data access provided for academic researchers in historical projects—is to promote a longer-term historical perspective on urban organization that can inform not only historical research but also modern day efforts to provide urban services. Furthermore, during the multi-year research process this project provided training and experience for 25 undergraduate students, two graduate students, and two postdoctoral scholars. The students learned skills such as textual analysis, coding, note-taking, and GIS-based spatial analysis.
